questions.prompt: The Southern Song and Northern Yuan were examples of these states that clung to power after dy nastic shifts.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Give this term for a small remnant ruled by a state that has been diminished by conquest or other losses.

B.question: The Seleucid [sel-YOO-sud] Empire was reduced to a rump state in Syria after the conquests of Mithridates I [mith-ruh-DATE-eez "the 1st"] of this Asian empire, known for its horse archers' tactic of firing while retreating.
B.answer: Parthian [PAR-thee-in] Empire (or Parthia or Parthians or Arsacid Empire or Arsacids; accept Parthian shot)

C.question: The Southern Ming became a rump state after this last dynasty of imperial China took power in 1644.
C.answer: (Great) Qing [cheeng] Dynasty (or Ch'ing Dynasty or Manchu Dynasty or Qing cháo)

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-name these locations of wintry mazes:

A.question: The largest ice maze in the U.S. is in the town of Stillwater in this state's Minneapolis -St. Paul metropolitan area.

B.question: In 2021 a massive snow maze was constructed in Saint Adolphe in this Canadian Prairie province, which lies directly west of Ontario.

C.question: At this European country's southern border along the Tatra Mountains, a large snow maze is among the attractions of Snowlandia in its so-called "Winter Capital" of Zakopane [zahk-koh-PAH-nay].
C.answer: Poland (or Republic of Poland or Rzeczpospolita Polska)

questions.prompt: Virtual pairs of these particles and their antiparticles create a phenomenon called a "sea."  For 10 points each -

A.question: A proton consists of three of what particles, whose flavors include "up" and "down"?
A.answer: quarks (accept quark sea or sea quarks)

B.question: The annihilation of sea quarks produces these particles, which are found along with quarks in a namesake type of plasma.

C.question: Because they have color charge, quarks and gluons have this property, meaning that they cannot exist in isolation.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about the May Laws of 1873:

A.question: The May Laws were part of this empire's attempt to suppress the Catholic Church during a "culture struggle."
A.answer: German Empire (or Germany; accept Deutsches Reich)

B.question: The German May Laws were the brainchild of this Prussian, who was nicknamed the "Iron Chancellor."
B.answer: Otto von Bismarck (or Otto Eduard Leopold, Fürst von Bismarck)

C.question: During the Kulturkampf, Bismarck promised that 19th-century Germany "would not go" to this place, an Italian fortress where medieval Emperor Henry IV ["the fourth"] did penance during the Investiture Controversy.
C.answer: Canossa [kuh-NOH-sah] (accept We will not go to Canossa or penance at Canossa or walk to Canossa)

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about people Donald Trump fired by tweet:

A.question: Rex Tillerson claimed that he learned of his firing from this office from a tweet.  Mike Pompeo [pahm-PAY-oh] held this diplomatic office later in the Trump administration.
A.answer: (United States) secretary of state (prompt on partial answers)

B.question: In September 2019 Trump tweeted the firing of this national security advisor, whose memoir of his time in the Trump administration is titled The Room Where It Happened.

C.question: Trump also used a tweet to dismiss this woman from her post as secretary of homeland security in April 2019.

questions.prompt: These numbers are the zeroes of cyclotomic [syk-loh-TAH-mik] polynomials.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Give this term for complex numbers that are solutions for x in the equation x to the n equals 1, where n is an integer.
A.answer: (nth) roots of unity (accept primitive roots of unity)

B.question: There are n solutions for x to the n equals 1 according to this theorem, which states that a polynomial of degree n has n complex roots.

C.question: Sometimes a root of a polynomial is repeated, which is known by this term.  For example, " x squared minus 2 x plus 1" has 1 as its only root, but the root "counts" twice.

questions.prompt: The 1999 Kargil War between India and Pakistan challenged many theories of international relations.  For 10 points each-

A.question: The war violated this German philosopher's claim that democracies would not fight each other, made in his 1795 book Perpetual Peace.

B.question: Both India and Pakistan had franchises of this fast food chain with a golden arches symbol, violating a theory similar to Kant's proposed by Thomas Friedman.

C.question: The war occurred despite both India and Pakistan having nuclear weapons, violating this theory with a three-word name that the threat of shared nuclear destruction prevents conflict.

questions.prompt: This character describes a dream he had about being pursued by a shrouded traveler, whom he later realizes was Death.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this narrator of a 1957 novel whose opening section depicts a trip to San Francisco.

B.question: Sal's travels across the U.S. and Mexico, and his friendship with Dean Moriarty, are depicted in this nov el.

C.question: On the Road is by Jack Kerouac ["CARE"-uh-wak], an author from this "generation" of 1950s counterculture writers that also included William S. Burroughs and Allen Ginsberg.
C.answer: Beat Generation (or Beat movement or Beats; accept beatnik)

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-name these films featuring Anne Hathaway:

A.question: In 2012 Hathaway starred as Fantine [fahn-teen] in a film adaptation of this musical about Jean Valjean [zhawn val-zhawn].

B.question: With Cate Blanchett and Sandra Bullock, Hathaway appeared in this 2018 heist movie about female criminals who steal a necklace at the Met Gala.
B.answer: Ocean's 8 (do not accept or prompt on answers mentioning any other number)

C.question: Hathaway starred as a con artist who tries to scam a tech billionaire in this 2019 remake of Dirty Rotten Scoundrels.

questions.prompt: These structures are composed of bundles called fascicles surrounded by an envelope known as epimysium [EP-ih-MISS-ee-um].  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name these structures responsible for body movement, which include the triceps [TRY-seps].
A.answer: skeletal muscles (accept, but do not otherwise reveal, striated muscles; do not accept or prompt on "smooth muscle(s)" or "cardiac muscle(s)")

B.question: In most cases, these tough bands of fibrous [FYE-brus] tissue connect muscles to bones.
B.answer: tendons (prompt on "sinew(s)"; do not accept or prompt on "ligament(s)") [Ligaments connect bone to bone, while tendons connect muscle to bone.]

C.question: This term refers to the banding of skeletal muscle that occurs because of the alignment of its functional units, or sarcomeres [SAR-koh-meers].

questions.prompt: Although this novel's title residence has a "dreary name," it becomes the beloved home of the narrator Esther Summerson.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this 1853 novel that describes a decades-long legal dispute over the Jarndyce [JARN-diss] estate.

B.question: Bleak House is a novel by this British author, who was paid by the installment to publish serial novels such as David Copperfield and Oliver Twist.
B.answer: Charles Dickens (or Charles John Huffam Dickens)

C.question: Dickens followed Bleak House with this novel set in the industrial city of Coketown, where Sissy Jupe [joop] attends a school run by the "facts"-obsessed Thomas Gradgrind.

questions.prompt: Antonio de Mendoza served as the first viceroy ["vice"-roy] of this territory.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this administrative unit created in 1535 that included modern-day Mexico and other colonies north of Panama.
A.answer: Viceroyalty of New Spain (or Virreinato de Nueva España)

B.question: Toward the end of New Spain's existence, 20 of these institutions were founded in what is now California.  Junipero Serra [hoo-NEE-"pair"-oh "sarah"] established nine of these religious centers.

C.question: Mexico became independent when the Spanish Empire began to disintegrate in this decade.  Napoleon's brother Joseph was driven out of Spain in the previous decade.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer these questions about the chemistry of mayonnaise:

A.question: As a stable mixture of oil and water, mayonnaise is what kind of suspension made of two immiscible [ih-MIH-sih-bul] liquids?
A.answer: emulsion(s) (prompt on "colloid(s)" or "colloidal (suspension)"; do not accept or prompt on "emulsification")

B.question: Mayonnaise's stability comes from the emulsifying agent lecithin ["LESS-uh-thin"], an example of what double-tailed compounds that often form "bilayers"?

C.question: Mayonnaise is flavored by either vinegar or lemon juice, which are what type of substance whose solutions have pHs less than 7?

questions.prompt: This author's plays include The Rules of the Game, which one of his later works featured as a play within a play.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this 20th-century author who wrote a play in which a rehearsal for The Rules of the Game is disrupted by the arrival of the title group.

B.question: The fraught relationship between a Father and a Stepdaughter is re-enacted in a Pirandello play about this many "Characters in Search of an Author."
B.answer: six (or sei; accept Six Characters in Search of an Author or Sei personaggi in cerca d'autore) [Six Characters in Search of an Author begins as actors are rehearsing Pirandello's The Rules of the Game.]

C.question: In another Pirandello play, a group of actors led by Doctor Hinkfuss perform thi s title action, which involves making up scenes and dialogue without a script.
C.answer: improvise (or recitare a soggetto; accept improvisation or improvising or improvised; accept Tonight We Improvise or Questa sera si recita a soggetto)

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about failed attempts to assassinate U.S. presidents:

A.question: The first presidential assassination attempt was made in 1835 against this seve nth president and signer of the Indian Removal Act, who beat his assailant with a cane.

B.question: This president was targeted twice in the same month, including by "Squeaky" Fromme [frohm], a follower of Charles Manson.
B.answer: Gerald Ford (or Gerald Rudolph Ford Jr. or Leslie Lynch King Jr.)

C.question: In 1981 John Hinckley Jr. shot and wounded Ronald Reagan in an attempt to impress this actress who appeared in Taxi Driver.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about organisms found near hydrothermal vents:

A.question: This term refers to organisms that thrive in conditions inhospitable to most life.  Many of these organisms live in the high-temperature environments near vents.

B.question: A so-called "city" of these animals lives among vents in American Samoa.  Moray ["MORE"-ay] and conger [rhymes with "longer"] are varieties of these snake-like fish.

C.question: Many extremophiles use this process of carbon fixation powered by the oxidation of inorganic compounds rather than sunlight.

questions.prompt: While a man inspects this object, Pip plays a tambourine.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Identify this object from a 19th-century novel that is created for a Polynesian harpooner, and to which another character clings to survive after he is cast adrift.

B.question: Queequeg's [KWEE-kweg's] coffin saves Ishmael following the sinking of the Pequod [PEE-kwahd], a ship commanded by this obsessive captain.

C.question: Queequeg, Ishmael, and Captain Ahab appear in this Herman Melville novel about the hunt for a white whale.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about disappearances in southeast Asia:

A.question: In April 2021 the submarine Nanggala II [nahn-"GALA" "two"] disappeared in waters north of this Indonesian island.  Beaches near its city of Denpasar [den-PAH-sar] are a major tourist destination.

B.question: Flight 370, which departed from this country's capital of Kuala Lumpur [koo-AH-lah lum-POOR], disappeared in March 2014.

C.question: Many disappearances of Tamil People on this island over the past 20 years have been linked to unmarked white vans-presumably connected to this island country's Sinhalese-dominated government.
C.answer: Sri Lanka [shree LAHN-kuh] (or Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka or Shri Lamka Prajatantrika Samajaya di Janarajaya or Ilankai Jananayaka Choshalichak Kutiyarachu)

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-name these baseball teams who had first-year managers in the 2018 season:

A.question: Alex Cora-who began managing this team in 2018-parted ways with this team in 2020 but rejoined as its manager in 2021 after serving a suspension for his role in the Astros sign-stealing scandal.
A.answer: Boston Red Sox (accept either underlined portion; prompt on "Sox")

B.question: Dave Martinez joined this team as manager in 2018, and led it to the 2019 World Series title over the Astros.
B.answer: Washington Nationals (accept either underlined portion; accept Nats)

C.question: In 2018 Mike Shildt [shilt] took over for Mike Matheny [muh-THEE-nee] in managing this NL team.
C.answer: St. Louis Cardinals (accept either underlined portion; accept Cards)

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about oaks in American history:

A.question: This Quaker founder of Philadelphia negotiated the purchase of lands from Lenape [LEH-nuh-pee] natives with a treaty signed under an oak tree in Graystones Forest.

B.question: A royal charter given to this colony in 1662 was supposedly hidden from Governor Edmund Andros inside of an old oak tree that became known as the "Charter Oak."

C.question: The extremely large Emancipation Oak is on the campus of this Virginia university.  Booker T. Washington attended this school when it was an agricultural institute.
C.answer: Hampton University (or Hampton Agricultural and Industrial School or Hampton Institute)

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about the philosophy of free will:

A.question: In contrast to determinists, believers in free will sometimes are known by this label, shared with a third party in the U.S. political system.

B.question: This theologian, the author of City of God, asked how free will can coexist with God's foreknowledge in his 5th-century dialogue De libero arbitrio [DAY lee-BEAR-oh ARR-bee-tree-oh].
B.answer: St. Augustine [aw-GUS-tin (or) AW-guh-steen] of Hippo (or Aurelius Augustinus Hipponensis; accept Saint Austin)

C.question: Free will results from an unpredictable "swerve" of these objects, according to Lucretius's [loo-KREE-shus's] poem On the Nature of Things.  Their name was coined by Democritus [deh-MAH-kri-tuss].

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about the Statue of Liberty:

A.question: The Statue of Liberty's interior framework was designed by this French engineer, who a lso designed an iron lattice tower in Paris.
A.answer: Gustave Eiffel (or Alexandre Gustave Eiffel; accept Alexandre Gustave Bönickhausen)

B.question: This French sculptor designed the statue's exterior.  He never realized his plans to design a massive lighthouse on the Suez Canal.

C.question: The green exterior of the Statue of Liberty comes from this pigment created by the weathering of copper.  It can be artificially created by applying acetic acid [uh-SEE-tik acid] to bronze.

questions.prompt: This territory's indigenous Kanak people called for a boycott of a 2021 referendum due to an ongoing period of mourning for local COVID deaths.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this island territory that rejected independence in that referendum.

B.question: New Caledonia is a territory of this European country, whose overseas regions include Guadeloupe [gwah-duh-LOOP].
B.answer: France (or French Republic or République française)

C.question: The Kanak independence movement advocates a "Melanesian" form of this political philosophy, whose "democratic" type is often contrasted with Marxism-Leninism.
C.answer: socialism (accept Melanesian socialism or democratic socialism)
